key_points: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez criticized for allegedly exaggerating her trauma from the Capitol riot.
Critics point out that Ocasio-Cortez wasn't in the Capitol building during the riot but in the Cannon building, part of the Capitol complex.
Ocasio-Cortez has spoken about her fear during the event and revealed she's a sexual assault survivor.
Rep. Katie Porter recounts Ocasio-Cortez seeking refuge in her office during the riot.
Rep. Nancy Mace (R-SC) contradicted Ocasio-Cortez, stating rioters did not storm their shared hallway.
Conservative journalist Jack Posobiec and Fox News host Tucker Carlson also criticized Ocasio-Cortez.
Ocasio-Cortez defended her statements, emphasizing the proximity and connectedness of her office to the Capitol.
Ocasio-Cortez called out on social media for allegedly misleading the public, compared to Jussie Smollett.
Ocasio-Cortez sent an email to supporters seeking help to report harassing or threatening posts.
The controversy sparked hashtags #AOClied and #AlexandriaOcasioSmollett; Ocasio-Cortez continued to defend her experience.
